Award.AbstractNarration:
Important applications in science and business depend on automatic classification of large volumes of items (examples) into predefined classes. Multi-label learning refers to the classification problem where each example can be assigned to multiple class labels simultaneously. The classification problem is germane to many different domains, such as natural language processing, computer vision, human computer interaction, bioinformatics, health care, and physiology. Existing machine learning technologies are unsuitable for large-scale multi-label learning because they are unable to handle rare class classification problems and poorly distinguish classes with similar input patterns.

To overcome the limitation of the existing approaches, the project is developing a relation propagation framework for multi-label learning that explicitly exploits the similarity of examples and the correlation among classes simultaneously. In particular, this project includes research to (1) develop efficient optimization algorithms for the proposed relation propagation framework; (2) develop effective algorithms for learning the similarity of examples and the correlation among classes; (3) develop effective active learning algorithms for multi-label learning; and (4) evaluate the proposed framework for multi-label learning through three real world applications: text categorization, image annotation, and prediction of gene expression patterns.

The project will advance the state of the art of techniques for large-scale multi-label learning through the development of relation propagation framework, which in return will have a significant impact on a wide range of applications. The research results will also enhance the current machine learning curricula, involve students in interdisciplinary research and improve the education of the information technology workforce. The project Web site (http://www.cse.msu.edu/~rongjin/) will be used for research results dissemination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Important applications in science and business depend on automatic classification. For example, automatic classification is used to automatically diagnose patients’ diseases based on their symptoms. Multilabel learning refers to the classification problem in which each example can be assigned to multiple class labels simultaneously. A well known example is text categorization, where every document can be assigned to multiple categories.

 Intellectual Merits: Most previous studies of multi-label learning are limited to no more than 100 classes. The proposed research focuses on large-scale multi-label learning problems that consist of thousands of classes. In particular, this project aims to address two fundamental challenges with large-scale multi-label learning, i.e., how to classify the rare categories, and how to classify categories with similar patterns. This research proposes to develop a relation propagation framework for multi-label learning that addresses both challenges. The key idea is to exploit the similarity of examples and the correlation among classes simultaneously through a construction of a relational graph. We have developed various techniques, including kernel learning, distance metric learning and matrix completion, to capture the data similarity and class correlation, and designed computational algorithms to efficiently solve the related optimization problems, including stochastic approximation, boosting, semi-definite programing, submodular functions and coordinate gradient descent. We have published 35 technical papers based on the theories and algorithms developed in this project.

 Broader Impact: Multi-label learning has found a number of real-world applications across a wide range of domains, such as computer science, biology, health care, music, and physiology. We have successfully applied the theories and algorithms developed in this project to multiple application domains, including bioinformatics, computer vision, human computer interaction, biometrics, and mine safety protection. The tools and software developed in this project has been used in the machine learning classes to provide students with hands-on experience. We also made the software available to the public through the project website. We have developed two seminar courses to help students from plant biology and chemical engineering understand the basic concepts and key techniques of machine learning.
